Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) = x(t) + iy(t) \\), where \\( x(t) \\) and \\( y(t) \\) are real functions defining the real and imaginary parts of \\( z \\), respectively. The function is subject to the differential equation \\( \\dot{z} = Wz \\), where \\( W \\) is a constant complex matrix. We study the effect of the transformation \\( f(z) = e^{Ut}z \\), where \\( U \\) is also a constant complex matrix, on the evolution of \\( z \\).

If the transformation \\( f(z) \\) is applied to a complex vector \\( z_0 \\) at \\( t = 0 \\), and then allowed to evolve under \\( \\dot{z} = Wz \\) without further intervention, will the state \\( z(t) \\) at \\( t = T \\) be the same as if \\( z_0 \\) was directly evolved to \\( t = T \\) under \\( \\dot{z} = Wz \\)?
Explanation: The transformation \\( f(z) = e^{Ut}z \\) modifies the initial state of the function at \\( t = 0 \\), changing its path of evolution. Depending on how matrix \\( U \\) relates to \\( W \\), especially if they do not commute, the trajectory of \\( z \\) can be altered fundamentally, resulting in a different state at \\( t = T \\).
